Argument: Statement1: To reduce waste of raw materials, the government of sperland is considering requiring household appliances to be broken down for salvage when discarded. Statement2: To cover the cost of salvage, the government is planning to charge a fee, which would be imposed when the appliance is first sold.
Premise1: Increasing the cost of disposing of an appliance properly increases the incentive to dispose of it improperly.
Premise2: Many nonfunctioning appliances that are currently discarded could be repaired at relatively little expense.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: To reduce waste of raw materials, the government of sperland is considering requiring household appliances to be broken down for salvage when discarded. Imposing the fee at the time of salvage won't reduce waste more effectively, however, because if customers tend to keep old appliances longer they are faced with a higher cost of repairs. Statement2: To cover the cost of salvage, the government is planning to charge a fee, which would be imposed when the appliance is first sold.

input_info.Q: Which of the following, if true, most seriously weakens the argument?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Many nonfunctioning appliances that are currently discarded could be repaired at relatively little expense.
input_info.O: Premise1: Increasing the cost of disposing of an appliance properly increases the incentive to dispose of it improperly.
input_info.P: Statement1: To reduce waste of raw materials, the government of sperland is considering requiring household appliances to be broken down for salvage when discarded. Imposing the fee at the time of salvage would reduce waste more effectively, however, because consumers tend to keep old appliances longer if they are faced with a fee for discarding them. Statement2: To cover the cost of salvage, the government is planning to charge a fee, which would be imposed when the appliance is first sold.

output: Statement1: A mathematical theorem proved by one mathematician should not be accepted until each step in its proof has been independently verified. Statement2: Computer-assisted proofs generally proceed by conducting a vast number of calculations -- surveying all the possible types of instances in which the theorem could apply and proving that the theorem holds for each type. Statement3: In every computer-assisted proofs which involve almost infinite number of steps are astronomically many types of instances to survey, and no human being could review every step in the proof. Statement4: Hence, computer-assisted proofs should not be accepted.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument relies?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Computers cannot be used to assist in generating proofs of mathematical theorems that involve only a very limited number of steps.
input_info.O: Premise1: The use of an independent computer program does not satisfy the requirement for independent verification of each step in a proof that is extended enough to be otherwise unverifiable.
input_info.P: Statement1: A mathematical theorem proved by one mathematician should not be accepted until each step in its proof has been independently verified. Statement2: Computer-assisted proofs generally proceed by conducting a vast number of calculations -- surveying all the possible types of instances in which the theorem could apply and proving that the theorem holds for each type. Statement3: In most computer-assisted proofs there are astronomically many types of instances to survey, and no human being could review every step in the proof. Statement4: Hence, computer-assisted proofs involving astronomically many types of instances should not be accepted.

Argument: Statement1: Although withholding information from someone who would find that information painful is sometimes justified, there is no such justification if the person would benefit from having the information. Statement2: Therefore, even though it would be painful for jason to learn that his supervisor is displeased with his work, his colleague jane should nonetheless inform jason of this fact, for knowing that his supervisor was displeased would enable jason to improve his supervisor's opinion of his work.
Premise1: Jason would benefit if he were able to improve his supervisor's opinion of his work.
Premise2: Jason might eventually improve his supervisor's opinion of his work even if he never learns that his supervisor is displeased with his work.

Please write the modified argument below:
output: Statement1: Withholding information from someone who would find that information painful is sometimes justified, because the truth will hurt him more than it will help. Statement2: Therefore, it would be painful for jason to learn that his supervisor is displeased with his work, his colleague jane should not inform jason of this fact, for knowing that his supervisor was displeased would put him in a bad mood and make him worse at his job.

input_info.Q: Which one of the following is an assumption on which the argument relies?
input_info.Om: Premise2: Jason might eventually improve his supervisor's opinion of his work even if he never learns that his supervisor is displeased with his work.
input_info.O: Premise1: Jason would benefit if he were able to improve his supervisor's opinion of his work.
input_info.P: Statement1: Although withholding information from someone who would find that information painful is sometimes justified, there is no such justification if the person would benefit from having the information. Statement2: Therefore, even though it would be painful for jason to learn that his supervisor is displeased with his work, his colleague jane should nonetheless inform jason of this fact, for knowing that his supervisor was displeased would enable jason to improve his supervisor's opinion of his work.

Argument: Statement1: Environmentalist : an increased number of oil spills and the consequent damage to the environment indicate the need for stricter safety standards for the oil industry. Statement2: Since the industry refuses to take action, it is the national government that must regulate industry safety standards. In particular, the government has to at least require oil companies to put double hulls on their tankers and to assume financial responsibility for accidents. Statement3: Industry representative : the industry alone should be responsible for devising safety standards because of its expertise in handling oil and its understanding of the cost entailed. Statement4: Implementing the double-hull proposal is not currently feasible because it creates new safety issues. Statement5: Furthermore, the cost would be burdensome to the industry and consumers.
Premise1: The only effective sources of increased stringency in safety standards for oil tankers are action by the industry itself or national government regulation.
Premise2: The requirement of two hulls on oil tankers, although initially costly, will save money over time by reducing cleanup costs.

output: Statement1: Environmentalist : an increased number of oil spills and the consequent damage to the environment indicate the need for stricter safety standards for the oil industry. In particular, the government has to at least require oil companies to put double hulls on their tankers and to assume financial responsibility for accidents. Statement4: Industry representative : the industry alone should be responsible for devising safety standards because of its expertise in handling oil and its understanding of the cost entailed. Statement5: Implementing the double-hull proposal is currently feasible because it doesn't creat new safety issues. Statement6: Furthermore, the cost wouldn't be burdensome to the industry and consumers.
